title: Wednesday, 29th November, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:07 am
BE11:07am

Yes, I know we're late, sorry.

BE11:08am

As in, completely. So I've spent the last ten minutes shifting everything over to Opera.

BE11:09am

Which of course means getting alerts like this .....

11:10 am
BE11:10am

BE11:10am

Just let me use the damn browser I want to use!

BE11:11am

Slack doesn't work at all on my PC because it can't recognise any of the brower numbers. Am I ranting now? Sorry. I'll get on.

11:11 am
undefined
BE11:11am

So! Best start with the scores.

BE11:12am

£ up, FTSE down.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Brexit breakthrough of sorts.

BE11:13am

Choose your newspaper depending on the reality you prefer.

BE11:13am

Telegraph reports a “final figure” for divorce of €45-€55bn. We report a liabilities worth €100bn, including temporary or contingent liabilities which unwind over time.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

No firm final figure to, I quote, "help Mrs May overcome political opposition from Brexiteers".

BE11:14am

Have Citi to summarise the rest.

BE11:15am

The Telegraph and the FT report that the UK side will try and “massage down” the headline bill by spreading payments over years, annually recalculating and discounting contributions to EU pensions and offsetting them with the UK’s share in the European Investment Bank (EIB). Also, the fall in sterling may bring down some of the UK’s payments. The Telegraph also reports that the UK would need to pay more than €20bn in net contributions during the two-year transition period the UK is seeking. EU diplomats told the FT that “France, Germany and other member states appear satisfied by the broad outlines of the deal”. The Telegraph reports that member states’ EU ambassadors will draft an EU summit statement on the progress of Brexit negotiations at a meeting on 6 December. Brexit impact analysis: The Brexit Committee has demanded that Brexit Secretary David Davis appears “very speedily indeed” to explain alleged redactions in the papers released to the committee on Monday. Otherwise, the Brexit secretary would be “held in contempt” by Parliament. The Guardian points out that the government is considering whether to try holding (and winning) another vote in Parliament to confirm that the released papers satisfy MPs.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

And here's what Citi reckons to it all.

BE11:16am

Chances of “sufficient progress” at the 14/15 December EU summit are rising. Besides the latest apparent break-through, we highlighted reports that the UK was also prepared to make major concessions on citizenship rights, while the Ireland border issue might be put on hold, given the latest political developments in Brussels. As predicted, the EU’s bargaining power in the negotiations proves very strong. While the ‘Brexit bill’ mostly crystallizes obligations that the UK would have if it stayed in the EU anyway (and the same is true for citizenship rights), these are politically contentious concessions in the UK. Brexit supporters may use upcoming parliamentary votes to vent their anger at the government or could even trigger a leadership contest in the Conservative party, making new elections more likely in turn.

BE11:17am

And HSBC.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

The moderate rally in sterling this morning - GBP-USD was up 0.5% - suggests the market may now be expecting a 'yes' from the EU to moving on to phase two of the talks in December. Certainly, this news on the financial settlement increases the chances of that, though it is not yet a foregone conclusion. The EU wants to see sufficient progress not only on the money, but also on the rights of citizens and the solution for the Northern Irish border. The UK could concede that citizens' rights would be guaranteed by the European Court of Justice, though this would be a second bruising concession in a short space of time. But the Northern Ireland issue, as Theresa May has said, may require some more creative thinking.

BE11:17am

Creative thinking? Sure. Put the border on a blockchain.

BE11:19am

Everyone crossing needs to carry an NFC chip and paste a QR code on the roofs of their cars. The border is monitored by autonomous drone zeppelins that scan the codes and add them to a blockchain.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

Anyone whose crossing isn't verified by the chain gets catapulted by some kind of trebuchet back to wherever they came.

BE11:21am

I'm available for consultancy work. Honestly, this stuff is not demonstrably worse than what's sitting on David Davis's desk.

undefined
11:21 am
BE11:21am

And onto stocks, I guess.

BE11:21am

Cineworld mentioned.

Cineworld Group PLC (CINE:LSE): Last: 581.00, down 113.5 (-16.34%), High: 668.50, Low: 575.50, Volume: 2.02m
11:21 am
BE11:22am

You'll remember Neil mentioned rumours around Regal Cinemas here a few weeks ago: https://ftalphavil...tslive/2017-11-08/

BE11:22am

What we didn't anticipate was that Cineworld -- a company that's half to a third the size of Regal -- would be a bidder. But here we are.

BE11:22am

Advanced talks.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Somewhat out of leftfield as, in addition to Regal being very big, the US isn't really a hot and exciting growth market to transform the investment case.

BE11:23am

They've had cinemas over there since 1896, so that's probably a quite mature market by any definition.

BE11:23am

And Regal itself is hardly underinvested or underperforming.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

And it's difficult to understand the synergies between a European cinema chain and a US one. Bulk buying of popcorn?

BE11:24am

Here's Peel Hunt to explain where we are.

BE11:24am

Regal has 561 cinemas in the US, with 7,315 screens, more than three times Cineworld’s number. It has an average of 13.0 screens per theatre, utilises Sony 4K Digital Projection and 68% of its cinemas feature premium amenities. In other words, it is a modern, well-invested multiplex estate

11:24 am
BE11:24am

(@WayneJ: you should copyright that before someone else does.)

BE11:24am

Cineworld intends to fund the potential acquisition through a mixture of incremental debt and a material equity raise by way of a rights issue, including a commitment to full subscription from Cineworld's 28% shareholder, Global City Holdings N.V. (which is owned by Cineworld’s CEO and COO).

BE11:25am

Thus, $23/share equates to 9.4x EV/EBITDA 2017E ($3,611m mkt cap + $2,116m net debt $611m) and 8.7x 2018E ($3,611m mkt cap + $2,087m net debt$656m). It also equates to a P/E of 24.1x 2017E and 21.7x 2018E. This compares to Cineworld’s 2018E valuation of 9.9x EV/EBITDA (£2,116m EV/£214m EBITDA) and P/E rating of 16.5x

11:24 am
BE11:25am

The acquisition EBITDA multiple is fair, in our view. Given the deal’s scale, the potential enhancement is large, but dependent on the synergies and the scale of the rights issue. Its scale and the potential range of outcomes make scenario-testing, such as the example below, to be highly speculative

BE11:25am

If synergies were 2% of costs (£50m), combined EBITDA could be £740m, relative to which the initial financial debt would be £4.5bn. To take this down to 3x net debt/EBITDA, we estimate the company would have to raise £2.3bn of equity; although it is possible that it may raise less than this.

BE11:25am

What synergies, tho?

11:26 am
BE11:26am

I'm still none the wiser. Sacking head office, maybe, but don't cinemas need a reasonable layer of local middle management to wrangle staff?

BE11:26am

We estimate that the deal would be 12% earnings accretive if the fundraise occurred at £6/share. With Regal having a $427m rent roll and a 6% cost of debt, we estimate a possible combined EBIT of £0.5bn, PBT of £365m, market cap of £3.9bn, EV £6.2bn, and EPS of 47p before factoring the rights issue discount.

BE11:27am

Panmure Gordon also.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Cineworld is developing a track record for deal making (following Cinema City deal in 2014), with a stated ambition to participate further in M&A as the cinema market consolidates. Admission numbers in mature markets like the US and UK have been fairly stable over the past few years and leading operators like Cineworld have an opportunity to act as industry consolidators. Cineworld revenues are currently 62% UK, 58% Europe/Israel, with no presence in the US, the world’s biggest cinema market. The Regal bid is an opportunistic chance to take share from US industry leader AMC Entertainment, whose shares have been struggling after its own acquisition spree (Odeon, Nordic Cinema), and give Cineworld more scale to fight increasing competition from digital players like Netflix.

BE11:28am

Our initial stab at the numbers suggests Cineworld could need to raise new equity in the order of £2.0bn, via a rights issue (c.1:1), which would include full subscription from Cineworld’s 28% shareholder Global City. We believe Cineworld could take ND/EBITDA to 3x (vs. PGe FY17 1.4x) for a transformation deal like this, as long as there is trajectory for leverage to normalise quickly. At 3x combined leverage and assuming no synergies we estimate Cineworld could finance the transaction 53% new equity and 47% debt, implying new equity of c.£2.0bn vs. Cineworld pre-deal market cap of £1.9bn. Some modest cost synergies are likely which could reduce the funding package required

BE11:29am

3x EBITDA that depends a lot on whether the public will ever tire of one new superhero film every six weeks.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Not really difficult to see why folks are a bit cautious of this one.

BE11:30am

Have UBS as well. They're sellers.

BE11:31am

Whilst consolidation in the cinema industry is a key theme currently, with benefits to being a larger global player in the market with increasing competitive threats, while also potentially providing better buying power, we believe the strategic logic looks questionable. As a US-only operator, Cineworld would be buying exposure to a mature market that looks increasingly challenged, with evidence of declining cinema admissions, and a highly competitive market with increasing levels of capex required. These are market dynamics that we view as key risks for Cineworld in the UK market already, and is one of the reasons we are more cautious on the future growth profile of the current group.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Better buying power of what? Surely not movies?

BE11:32am

Because which movie studio plays hardball on price rather than having their movie in as many screens as possible? So .... it must be popcorn.

BE11:32am

Regal Entertainment has 561 theatres and 7.315 screens in the US. Given the size of Regal, the combined group would generate c.75% of revenues (based on FY16 numbers and a 1.3 exchange rate) from the mature US market, with less than 10% of revenues and c.14% of profits from the faster-growing Central Eastern European markets. Given one of the key pillars of our investment case is the exposure to structurally growing cinema markets in Eastern European; we see this potential acquisition as weakening the core investment case.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Nuts.

BE11:07am

Chrome decided to stop working at 10.55am.

undefined
11:34 am
BE11:34am

BARCLAYS IS SAID TO WARN HALF OF BANKERS AT RISK OF PAY CUTS

BE11:34am

That's Bloomberg.

BE11:35am

And, uh, good? The IB's been underperforming badly against market expectations, which you'd assume are the same as internal expectations.

11:34 am
Barclays PLC (BARC:LSE): Last: 192.80, up 5.45 (+2.91%), High: 193.45, Low: 189.65, Volume: 20.49m
BE11:35am

INVESTMENT BANK CHIEF SAID TO WIDEN DIVISION IN BONUSES FOR '17

BE11:36am

No idea what that means.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Anyway, let's get on.

BE11:37am

Was there a request earlier for Stagecoach or did I imagine it?

Stagecoach Group PLC (SGC:LSE): Last: 170.70, up 10.8 (+6.75%), High: 172.90, Low: 159.60, Volume: 686.59k
11:38 am
BE11:39am

(@Tom: I don't get invited to the meetings where we decide the company line on pressing issues of the day, sorry.)

BE11:40am

Liberum goes positive on Stagecoach on the East Coast franchise rejig.

BE11:40am

The problems and challenges at the East Coast rail franchise have weighed on Stagecoach's rating. New plans by the DfT to replace the franchise early, in 2020, and to negotiate revised terms to cover the period until then, are positive for Stagecoach. Details of the revised terms are still to be negotiated, but we see them as being no worse to Stagecoach than at present. Importantly, we believe the risk of the group defaulting on the franchise has been removed. The reduction in risk and uncertainty should improve confidence in the 7.5% dividend yield. We upgrade our recommendation to BUY from Hold, with an unchanged SOTP-based TP of 170p.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

This is Stagecoach's 90/10 JV with Virgin which was meant to run until at least March 2023.

BE11:41am

But now we're getting a "Partnership" franchise from 2020 that's meant to join up the buses and the trains, in a way that Britain never ever does.

BE11:41am

The East Coast franchise is problematic for both Stagecoach and the DfT. Revenue growth since Stagecoach took over the franchise in March 2015 has fallen short of expectations. This left Stagecoach facing the challenge of meeting contracted premium payments to the government in the face of lower revenue than forecast. Despite the short-term challenges, much depended on infrastructure upgrades by Network Rail, scheduled for completion by 2019. These would have improved journey times and increased capacity. Stagecoach's long-term revenue growth assumptions relied upon these infrastructure improvements to generate additional growth. However, it is clear that Network Rail will not deliver the required infrastructure upgrade in 2019 (if at all). Network Rail is owned by the government, so the DfT is responsible for its shortcomings. Consequently, both sides needed to find a way out of the problematic East Coast contract.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

No details, of course, but the idea here is that Stagecoach has already booked a £84m provision so it might now be less than that.

BE11:42am

In valuation terms ....

BE11:43am

On our current published forecasts, Stagecoach trades on an April 2018E P/E of 8.0x, EV/EBITDA (ex-rail cash) of 4.9x and dividend yield of 7.5%. We see the valuation on traditional multiples as attractive, although our enthusiasm had previously been tempered by the risks in Rail (which have diminished significantly today) and headwinds to revenue growth in UK Bus (which remain, but may have stabilised). Although it is unclear how much value the changes to the East Coast franchise might add, we see them as neutral at worst.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

Also, RBC .....

BE11:45am

It is not yet clear to us what impact this may have on the contingent equity required to be funded, so potentially this could be negative if Stagecoach ended up funding losses (up to the maximum of the contingent equity), then had a short-duration low-margin direct ward, and then had to bid for any profitable replacement. This likely raises a question of whether the long-term benefits of rail would still be worth the short-term cost and time - or whether the company may not be better off by exiting East Coast. In our view, the transition to the new alliance contract will need to be meaningfully profitable and long to justify continued involvement in UK Rail.
Elsewhere, East Midlands will see a contract extension (direct award) and Stagecoach is shortlisted for South Eastern.
Our view: Today’s news creates more short-term uncertainty on the financial economics of UK rail – but with scope for a potentially more viable/sustainable model to emerge (but with lots of work for the DFT to do to work out an ‘alliance’ model that will work in practice).
Short-duration contract extensions are helpful, but on East Coast we think the risk losses currently incurred will likely no longer offer scope for a re-based contract to 2023 or longer – so looks like a net (but hard to quantify) negative to us, on first impression.

BE11:45am

And Jefferies.

11:45 am
BE11:46am

From the Train Operating Companies' point of view, as long as the intended changes are explicit in the contracts that the groups are asked to bid for (which presumably will be the case) then these groups will have the opportunity to reflect any change in responsibility in future franchises in the terms of future bids. Because we do not reflect much value within our SOTP approach to sector valuation beyond currently contracted franchises (we only include a risk weighted value for any shortlisted prospects), the implication of future alliance structures has minimal impact on our sector view. We will continue to consider each new future contract as it becomes shortlisted (by when there should be some visibility around each intended structure).

FirstGroup PLC (FGP:LSE): Last: 108.60, up 2 (+1.88%), High: 108.60, Low: 106.30, Volume: 1.34m
undefined
11:47 am
BE11:47am

Haven't mentioned LSE ......

London Stock Exchange Group PLC (LSE:LSE): Last: 3,740, down 60 (-1.58%), High: 3,748, Low: 3,710, Volume: 514.00k
BE11:49am

... Haven't really mentioned LSE at all here, in part because it looks a lot like a small gang of superannuated guys having a bit of a gripe at each other.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

In a civilised society it would all be settled in a pub car park, but instead we get .....

BE11:50am

Xavier Rolet will step down as CEO with immediate effect;

BE11:50am

Donald Brydon, current Chairman, will not seek reelection in 2019

11:50 am
BE11:50am

David Warren, current CFO, will assume CEO responsibilities on an interim basis

BE11:51am

(@Pharma: fair point.)

BE11:51am

Citi's Owen Jones can write the eulogy for Rolet.

11:51 am
BE11:52am

For better or worse, this saga will feature in corporate governance textbooks. Xavier Rolet agreed to stand aside initially as part of the planned, but ultimately ill-fated, merger with Deutsche Borse. When this was blocked by the European Commission, he resumed his responsibilities as CEO with comments that he was fully committed to the task at hand. In June 2017, Mr Rolet presented the group’s updated strategic ambitions, which run until 2019, and then came the news on 19 October that Mr Rolet was to leave the group by the end of 2018. The timing of this was unusual, given the proximity of the events, but did not come as a surprise necessarily given Mr Rolet’s apparent willingness to leave the LSEG as part of the DB1 merger.

BE11:52am

Throughout this affair, there have been more questions than answers. This, in part, is why TCI, which owns ~5% of the LSEG, decided to challenge the decision of the LSE board. To judge the performance of a CEO only by the company’s share price is, perhaps, too simple a metric; however, in the case of Mr Rolet, under his stewardship the shares have risen by ~460% and outperformed the market by ~380%. It is, perhaps, how he achieved these gains internally that ultimately led to the current situation. The LSE board has decided to back its Chairman and not the most prominent architect of its recent success.

BE11:52am

The Rolet P/E Premium? – More so than any other Exchange under coverage, Mr Rolet featured prominently as part of the LSE’s investment case. The original succession plan was for Mr Rolet to have a say in who his successor would be. This, we understand, will no longer be the case. He is pro-European, an enthusiastic advocate of ‘Open Access’ and has maintained an excellent network of industry contacts. A key question for shareholders now is whether or not his departure will impact the market rating on the company’s shares.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

He remains a buyer, concluding with .....

BE11:53am

We await the permanent CEO appointment. Shareholders now
have time to decide whether or not a ~460% increase in the shares is likely over the next decade or so.

BE11:54am

As I say, the pub car park option would've been much cleaner.

11:54 am
undefined
BE11:54am

Alright then, Dixons.

Dixons Carphone PLC (DC.:LSE): Last: 163.60, up 9.6 (+6.23%), High: 165.50, Low: 153.00, Volume: 4.71m
11:56 am
BE11:56am

It's mostly just a sector squeeze on sterling, isn't it?

BE11:56am

You've also got Kingfisher up ....

Kingfisher PLC (KGF:LSE): Last: 336.50, up 13.5 (+4.18%), High: 337.50, Low: 323.30, Volume: 7.55m
11:56 am
BE11:57am

And even Marks.

Marks and Spencer Group PLC (MKS:LSE): Last: 308.10, up 7.1 (+2.36%), High: 309.90, Low: 302.50, Volume: 6.14m
BE11:58am

General retail sector's up 2% and Dixons is consensus short ahead of interims mid December, so not a big surprise to see it move.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

If there is something else, I haven't seen it.

undefined
BE12:00pm

So anyway, that's through midday.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

Neil's going to be around tomorrow, thankfully, so expect session quality to springboard from today's dismal levels.

BE12:02pm

Thanks for joining and, until then, have a good afternoon.

BE11:33am

I'd make a joke about empire building, tied to the fact that Cineworld operates the Empire in Leicester Square, but I can't think of one so add your own joke here.
